column3: American post questions Nashville Mayor's closure of bars
column4: The post submitted for review asks whether or not Nashville Mayor John Cooper deliberately over-stated COVID-19 case count to motivate closure of bars.
column5: The Mayor has not over-stated the COVID-19 case count iro Nashville bars. The claim has been fact-checked here: https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2020/09/18/fact-check-nashville-mayor-cooper-coronavirus-stats/3491786001/. The post in question appears to be on a media site that seems to be deliberately skewing news and information about COVID
column6: Resolved

column3: Instant COVID-19 tests for sale
column4: The complaint references a WhatsApp message that purports to be selling rapid/instant COVID-19 tests.
column5: This information appears to be inaccurate and misleading. The South African Health Products Regulatory Authority (SAHPRA) has indicated
column6: in line with the South African National Institute for Communicable Disease (NICD) and the World Health Organization (WHO) have indicated that it COVID-19 tests should be conducted by a health care professional and processed by a certified laboratory to ensure accuracy of decision-making
column7: treatment and advice. This message is therefore likely to be a scam and members of the public should treat it with caution. SAHPRA has appealed to the public to report to SAHPRA any company/individual/website selling COVID-19 Rapid test kits so that SAHPRA can take the necessary action in this regard.

column3: False claims regarding Zimbabweans stealing jobs used to mobilise march
column4: The post uses unverified numbers to claim that Zimbabweans are stealing jobs. The hashtags relied on are known to be popular for perpetuating an anti-foreigner sentiment. Included in the post is a call for South African citizens to participate in a march to the Nigerian Embassy on 23 September 2020.
column5: Content circulated under the #PutSouthAfricaFirst hashtag is dangerous and typically seeks to exploit the volatile nature of this issue. High unemployment rates have caused this to be an even more emotionally-driven matter and this sentiment is harnessed to perpetuate a xenophobic narrative. While this post does not fulfil the legal criteria for hate speech
column6: it does constitute disinformation. The matter has been reported to Xenowatch.
column7: Resolved

column3: Hyperbolic
column4: untrue claims re. persecution of Boerevolk
column5: An image and accompanying copy make a number of statements regarding the alleged persecution of the Boerevolk in South Africa. One of these is that there are 119 laws discriminating on grounds of (white) race.
column6: There are not 119 laws discriminating on grounds of white people's skin colour. Article nine of the Constitution states that no South African may be discriminated against on the basis of race or sex
column7: unless discrimination is fair. The claims stated in the graphic are either blatantly untrue or hyperbolic. The categorisation of boerevolk is also overly-broad and perhaps even inaccurate. In this instance
column8: misinformation is used to exacerbate already-strained racial tensions and increase fear and hostility. However
column9: while it should be clearly marked as misinformation
column10: in the interests of freedom of expression
column11: sentiments and statements such as this should be ventilated and disproven
column12: rather than be removed off Twitter.

column3: Misinformation from anti-vaxxer Robert F. Kennedy Jr. (lawyer
column4: not doctor)
column5: The Whatsapp message claims to be a message from Robert F Kennedy Jnr advising against a COVID-19 vaccine. The resource url links to his Wikipedia page. The Whatsapp starts with To all my patients: RF Kennedy Jnr.
column6: This is misinformation. The message is harmful: (1) It positions R Kennedy's message as 'official' as it appears on Wikipedia; (2) it positions Robert Kennedy as a medical doctor
column7: as it begins 'to all my patients; and (3) Robert F Kennedy has spread multiple conspiracy theories about COVID-19 and vaccinations. This is a clear attempt to stop people from ever having a vaccination

column3: False claim re. internet shutdown brought by Quantum Internet
column4: The post states that the Quantum Internet will cause the whole Internet on THE PLANET to switch off
column5: and thanks a conspiracy theorist
column6: Daniel Dowell (https://web.facebook.com/daniel.dowell.7773) for the information.
column7: This is fake news. The Quantum Internet is still not widely implemented or clearly defined in terms of what it will do and the activities for which it will be used. It not 'switch off' the current Internet or shutdown existing social media platforms. There is no evidence to suggest it would do so. It is recommended that Daniel Dowell's Facebook profile be investigated for the perpetuation of QAnon content.

column3: A post claiming the negative effects of wearing a mask on the brain
column4: This complaint pertains to a Facebook post in which the user claims to be presenting the first hand comments of a supposedly world renowned Neurologist who claims that wearing a facial mask
column5: in response to COVID-19
column6: can cause varying degrees of brain damage due to oxygen deprivation and other related complications.
column7: Contrary to the claims made in the post
column8: wearing a mask does not restrict the amount of oxygen a person breathes in (and therefore the amount that reaches your brain) and it also does not cause a dangerous buildup of carbon dioxide. Similar claims related to the same notion have already been debunked by several reputable information agencies
column9: including Poynter: https://www.poynter.org/fact-checking/2020/it-is-not-true-that-masks-cause-hypoxia-this-hoax-is-now-viral-and-dangerous/. Further areas of concern raised by the posts are also addressed here: https://www.cnet.com/health/8-dangerous-covid-19-face-mask-myths-you-need-to-stop-believing/.   Additionally
column10: an internet search of the supposed expert Dr. Margarite Griesz-Brisson results in various iterations of this post indicating the likelihood that it is a common iteration of misinformation.

column3: Disinformation with xenophobic agenda re. Orange Farm child murder accused
column4: The tweet purports to depict the woman who allegedly murdered two children in Orange Farm. The tone of the accompanying text assumes a strong xenophobic stance.
column5: While the picture has been confirmed as not depicting the suspect
column6: news reports confirm that the person accused of the murder is in fact a foreigner (https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2020-10-01-new-twist-in-orange-farm-child-killings-as-woman-appears-in-court/ ) However
column7: the overall effect of the wording is to incite xenophobic hatred. The fact that an image is incorrectly associated with a message that furthers a xenophobic sentiment is disinformation as it was intended to mislead.

column3: Deadly Second Wave of New Disease in November
column4: The Voicenote claims we'll have a second lockdown in November that is more strict because there is a 'new disease' coming that's 'very deadly'. It also claims there will be no production and therefore no food. As there is no evidence and no sources cited to support any of the claims made in the voice note.
column5: This is Disinformation with the first red flag being the lack of the credibility and support for the information provided. It claims we'll have a second lockdown in November that is more strict because there is a 'new disease' coming that's 'very deadly'. It also claims there will be no production and therefore no food. As there is no evidence to support any of the claims made in the voice note
column6: it is imperative that a Infographic be issued to mark it as FAKE because it only serves to inspire panic in the population.
column7: Resolved

column3: Tweet claiming that Southern Africa is sitting on a huge time bomb as it relates to a new unknown virus
column4: This complaint pertains to a tweet in which the user
column5: who identifies himself as a professor
column6: warns the reader about a new unknown virus as well as the relaxation of protective measures will result in a second wave.
column7: While there are various theories around the potential for a second wave
column8: as well as scientists whose opinion is that Covid-19 will not be the last new virus we see
column9: the claims made in the tweet tend towards the outrageous and extreme
column10: without providing any form of fact or evidence to support the claims made. As the user positions themselves as a medical professional
column11: my concerns are that they could incite panic amongst people
column12: which could manifest in all manner of things
column13: from outrageous conspiracy theories to potentially harmful 'cures'.
column14: Resolved

column5: While this content may be portraying a particular view that could engender distrust around vaccines
column6: and while there may be portions of the video that could be misleading
column7: overall this content does not appear to meet all the requirements for mis- or disinformation.

column3: Attempt at satire features SA cartoonist
column4: The original image depicts some of the 13 men implicated in a kidnap plot of the Governer of Michigan but the composite image included in this tweet has been edited to include a profile shot of the South African cartoonist Jeremy Nell (known as Jerm).
column5: Jeremy Nell (Jerm) was clearly not involved in the kidnap plot. It would seem that the author/ creator of the tweet and the accompanying image intended for this to be an attempt at satire.
column6: Resolved

column3: Insinuation of genocide constitutes disinformation
column4: Two tweets were submitted for review
column5: the one containing hateful
column6: racist language and the other (since deleted)
column7: insinuating that the South African government was involved in planning genocide of the boers by deploying the army to Senekal. This claim could not be verified in any news reports.
column8: Language and imagery suggesting genocide of the boers is disinformation
column9: and drives a divisive agenda that is likely to worsen public unrest. While the language contained in the primary tweet is hateful and racist
column10: it fails to satisfy all legal criteria for hate speech as no incitement to cause harm is present.

column3: Misguided tweet on IQ difference between races
column4: The tweet claims that certain races are less intelligent.
column5: This is a false claim made to further a racist agenda. While it is deplorable
column6: and clearly misinformation
column7: it does not meet the legal criteria of causing public harm. It is a misguided personal opinion that reveals its author to be a racist.

column3: Tweet and associated video of Julius Malema claiming that
column4: inter alia
column5: violence
column6: rape and murder were not present in South Africa but instead were brought to the country in 1652 by white people
column7: This complaint pertains to a tweet and video in which EFF leader
column9: makes the claim that that violence came here on a ship in 1652 through a white man. Rape was brought by a white man
column10: abuse was brought by a white man
column11: murder was brought by a white man
column12: killing of children was brought by a white man here in South Africa.
column13: While the content is of a hyperbole nature the reasonable processing of the content results in an inaccurate information standard being met: the content alleges
column14: even once hyperbole is discounted
column15: that the arrival of white people to South Africa is the cause of the countries violent criminal conduct. This claim is not substantiated and is possibly false
column16: inaccurate or misleading as it cannot be supported from the content alone.   Even though the tweet and video are inflammatory in nature
column17: they do not meet the criteria for hate speech in the strictest sense as per this platform. Whilst there is an advocacy of hatred against another person on the basis of race
column18: there is no incitement to cause harm. Whilst Malema calls for his followers to 'go fight white violence'
column19: in light of ongoing rhetoric it is not guaranteed to be a call to cause harm to white people.
column20: Resolved

column3: Julius Malema's speech at Senekal - allegation of hate speech and incitement to violence
column4: Julius Malema's speech was submitted for review by a complainant as the complainant felt that: (1) it amounted to hate speech; and (2) it constituted incitement to violence.
column5: The words spoken do not meet the full legal criteria for hate speech because the overarching message was not one that constituted advocacy to hatred against another person nor did it constitute incitement to cause harm in terms of the legal criteria. The words also did not satisfy the legal test for incitement to violence
column6: as it could not be reasonably expected that the natural and probable consequences of this speech under the circumstances would be the commission of public violence. ;However
column7: it has been noted that At around 10:25 in the YouTube video
column8: Julius Malema states that there is [sic] no farm murders in South Africa. There are no farmers who are being killed
column9: and this message must reach that racist Trump. There are no white farmers being killed in South Africa. In South Africa
column12: there are children being killed... If one interprets this statement literally
column13: it is capable of being proven incorrect
column14: based on facts. It is clearly an exaggerated statement to illustrate that in Malema's opinion
column15: the cause of violence against women and children is much more worthy of highlighting than that of violence against farmers - and also to discredit the untrue claim of white genocide. This hyperbolic
column16: unnuanced way of expression to advance a political agenda could be seen as misinformation - or even disinformation. It is also not impossible that the speaker intended the statement to mislead - or did not care that some would be misled by it.
column17: Resolved
column18: Youtube

column3: Voice notes circulated via WhatsApp alleging that a move to lockdown level 3 is imminent
column4: This complaint pertains to a series of voice notes in which the speaker alleges that a move to lockdown level 3 is scheduled for the end of November 2020 and that as a result thereof shops will be closed.   The complaint is that this is mis- or disinformation.
column5: While another lockdown cannot be totally ruled out there is no evidence to suggest that it will be at the end of November nor that it will be immediate
column6: nor that supplies in shops will run out.  There is also a racial warning about white people needing to protect themselves against black people which in itself is an unfounded claim to make. The person also says the lockdown will be months and months long. Many of the claims made are entirely unfounded
column7: but given the paranoia currently raging across nation
column8: it is imperative that such content be dismissed as FAKE.

column3: Statement re. Konrad Koch/ Chester Missing
column4: A video clip featuring Konrad Koch/ Chester Missing using hateful words (during a comedy performance) is used to drive the point that they are guilty of hate speech. The tweet fails to mention the comedic context of the dialogue
column5: which is crucial to the understanding thereof.
column6: The complaint was framed as journalist harassment. While this does not fall within the legal definition of journalist harassment
column7: it does constitute disinformation. The act of using a video clip featuring comedic expression that is protected in terms of section 16(1) of the Constitution
column8: out of context to imply that Conrad Koch/ Chester Missing is guilty of hate speech
column9: shows a deliberate intent to mislead to further a particular agenda. This constitutes misleading content
column10: which is a sub-category of disinformation (please see p. 47 (https://en.unesco.org/sites/default/files/journalism_fake_news_disinformation_print_friendly_0.pdf)

column3: Post cites incorrect information from Liberty Fighters Network to dissuade wearing of masks
column4: The poster is encouraging people to not wear masks and not to social distance. She is using information from an unauthorised source called Liberty Fighters Network to say the government is acting illegally by enforcing measures to keep people safe during the pandemic.
column5: The author of the post is misleading people by placing misguided reliance on information that is not true. It is a risk to COVID-19 precaution measures. Such a court order was not issued. On the 2nd June a judgment and associated order of the North Gauteng Division relating to the disaster management regulations was issued: http://www.saflii.org/za/cases/ZAGPPHC/2020/184.html However such matter remains pending in the courts (at least the majority of the matter) and even if the decision taken is the last word on the matter the minister is required to re-promulgate regulations and the claims made on Facebook are therefore misleading at best. The complainant may wish to report the post to Facebook by taking the following steps: https://www.facebook.com/help/181495968648557
column6: Resolved

column5: claiming superiority of Hitler's Nazi regime (in terms of eugenics) was submitted for review.
column6: We currently do not have enough evidence to conclusively rule this post as fake - nor can we verify it as legitimate. We note that the South African Human Rights Commission has condemned the incident and will be conducting its own investigation into the allegations of racism at the school. It is hoped that an investigation of this nature will involve amongst other things
column7: the scrutiny of messaging such as the post submitted for review to establish its veracity.

column3: @Jonathan_Witt: Tweet regarding Covid19 and Real411 Platform
column4: Jonathan Witt claims that Real411's factcheckers only have BA degrees and that the site is sponsored by George Soros and furthermore Witt is not arguing that the efficacy of certain measures is less than that of other measures and therefore warrants assessment prior to their use
column5: but rather categorically that they have no efficacy at all. This could result in members of the public taking no precautions and being reckless.
column6: CORRECTION: Whilst the outcome decision stands
column7: we apologize for any confusion caused. Real411.org does receive financial support from the Donors listed on the site - this includes the Open Society Foundation of South Africa
column9: does receive its funds from Mr George Soros. The Secretariat consists of 5 legal professionals none of whom receive any remuneration for doing so. The Secretariat do not work in an NGO environment and were unaware of the connection between Open Society Foundation and Mr George Soros.  Neither Open Society Foundation (or Mr George Soros) nor any other Donors have any say or influence whatsoever in the process
column10: reviews and outcomes of Real411.org. Any such insinuation or statement is vexatious and should be dismissed as such.   For more about how the system work

column12: not every reviewer for Real411 has a BA degree (nor is this a qualification that would deny them the knowledge they need to be able to vet the content of Witt's tweet) nor is there any evidence to suggest that the platform is funded by George Soros. All claims made by Witt in an attempt to defend his decision to post misinformation are unfounded and inaccurate

column3: Tweet describing the result of measures taken by airports as result of COVID-19
column4: This complaint pertains to a tweet in which the author of the tweet describes his experience at an airport as a result of measures taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition thereto
column5: the Twitter user refers to propaganda being broadcast via the airport speaker system and that all of these measures have been taken as a result of a fake pandemic.  The complaint is that labelling the pandemic as fake is misinformation.
column6: The assertion of a fake pandemic is made as a statement of fact and objectively false and misleading. This is based on the fact that the coronavirus outbreak was labelled a pandemic by the World Health Organisation (WHO) on the 11th of March 2020.   This statement could reasonably be construed to cause public harm as it may encourage people to not take the measures necessary
column7: especially during air travel
column8: to protect themselves and others.  There are no overarching public interest considerations in favour of the continued publication of the information
column9: such as considerations of satire or parody.

column3: Swedish mortality rates used to question efficacy of lockdown
column4: The tweet cites Swedish mortality statistics to support the idea that South Africa may have overreacted to COVID-19 by implementing measures such as a lockdown.
column5: The tweet submitted for review does not meet all the criteria for misinformation. It is noted that the narrow interpretation of the statistics seems to disregard the nuances necessary to reach a conclusion that the Swedish approach resulted in unnecessary deaths. A number of credible scientific sources list numerous concerns with the Swedish approach. Until such time as it can be conclusively proven as a success based on a holistic interpretation of the statistics
column6: it cannot be publically touted by a medical professional as being a viable solution suitable for application in South Africa. https://time.com/5899432/sweden-coronovirus-disaster/ https://www.medpagetoday.com/infectiousdisease/covid19/89017 https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2020/10/it-s-been-so-so-surreal-critics-sweden-s-lax-pandemic-policies-face-fierce-backlash
column7: Resolved

column7: amongst other things

column9: it is too soon to conclusively proclaim from a public platform that there's indefinite immunity. http://www.idm.uct.ac.za/news/studying-the-immune-systems-response-to-covid-19 Furthermore
column10: while the efficacy of cloth masks is not infallible
column11: they are generally viewed as one of the most effective large-scale measures (used in conjunction with other measures such as social distancing) to curb the spread of COVID-19: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-02801-8

column3: Jonathan Witt responds to accusation of bullying
column4: Complainant states: Jonathan Witt refers to Real411 as a 'foreign funded propaganda platform' in an attempt to call into question the integrity of its reviews
column5: which he has a problem with since his tweets were reported and found to be problematic.
column6: As previously stated
column7: Real411 is not influenced in any way by its funders and reviewers are volunteers and therefore not financially dependent on Real411 or its funders.  The Oxford Dictionary defines propaganda as Information
column8: especially of a biased or misleading nature
column9: used to promote a political cause or point of view. Presumably
column10: Jonathan Witt makes the assertion that Real411 is a propaganda platform due to the fact that it aligns itself with the views of certain organisations
column11: such as the World Health Organisation. In a climate where even expert opinions are divided on medical best practice and public health policy (eg. wearing of masks) - it seems prudent to endorse the approach of publically-recognised and endorsed institutions. Due to the scale and gravity of the matter
column12: while there may be some merit in the less cautious approaches
column13: one cannot endorse these until there is conclusive proof that they are more favourable (safer) than those that are officially endorsed.   Debate re. masks: https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-02801-8
column14: Resolved

column3: Tweet promoting wariness surrounding the efficacy or claims of efficacy of masks and cloth masks
column4: This complaint pertains to a tweet in which the author of the tweet is supporting the assertion that the 'masks work' doctrine is unfalsifiable. Additionally
column5: the author alludes to research against the efficacy of cloth masks and that one must be wary of unfalsifiable claims in general.   The complaint is that the author of the tweet is attempting to encourage people to disregard the safety precaution of wearing a mask.
column6: Whilst the tweet linked to the tweet forming the basis of this complaint makes a thinly veiled commentary on the masks work doctrine as being not without reproach
column7: the tweet in question does not definitively state that masks
column9: are ineffective nor that the use thereof should be discouraged.   The tweet author is ostensibly alluding to research conducted in which the efficacy of cloth masks has been tested and that the result thereof is that there efficacy is questionable.   Research has determined that the filtration
column12: and performance of cloth masks are inferior to those of medical masks and respirators. Cloth mask use should not be mandated for healthcare workers
column13: who should as a priority be provided proper respiratory protection. Cloth masks are a more suitable option for community use when medical masks are unavailable. Protection provided by cloth masks may be improved by selecting appropriate material
column14: increasing the number of mask layers
column15: and using those with a design that provides filtration and fit. Cloth masks should be washed daily and after high-exposure use by using soap and water or other appropriate methods.  As such the tweet does not constitute misinformation as it is partially correct however the context of the statement must be considered taking the above into consideration.   Sources:  https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/5/4/e006577 https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2020/08/200825113635.htm https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/26/10/20-0948_article
column16: Resolved

column6: it did not seem true.
column7: A number of sweeping statements
column8: unverified by facts and no particulars included (the identity of the they referred to
column10: have been made in this tweet. While some contain elements of truth
column11: the vague nature thereof may cause people to entirely dismiss the need to have a COVID test - even in cases where it is necessary. While the author's intention may not have been for this to happen
column12: care is needed when publishing statements of a medical nature pertaining to COVID-19 on a public platform - especially as a HCW. To say that COVID is being retrofitted onto the death certificate can also be broadly interpreted as standard practice
column13: when this may not factually be so. No evidence
column14: even anecdotal
column15: was provided by Witt to confirm this point and it could not be verified when discussed with other public sector HCWs.  REASONING: The statement contains the following claims: (1) They're swabbing cadavers for undiagnosed SARS-CoV-2; (2) then running a test known for producing false positives; and (3) retrofitting COVID onto the death certificate. The problem is that at no point are details given regarding the identity and/ or location of the collective referred to as they. This statement could thus be interpreted very broadly
column16: which may lead to a conclusion that each of the actions mentioned is standard practice. According to guidelines issued by the Department of Health
column17: the collection and submission of COVID-19 postmortem specimens from all people who died of natural causes outside health facilities are required: https://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Guidelines-on-Post-Mortem-Testing-for-Natural-Deaths_2020_Final_signed_20201013.pdf Regarding that statement: running a test known for producing false positives - while this has been documented

column19: rather than qualified
column20: statement regarding the current rate of operational false-positive swab tests.

column7: The information provided is false. However
column9: it does not meet the criteria of causing public harm. Fact checking this information prior to tweeting would have been a straightforward exercise and ensured that such false information was not further disseminated.
column14: Jerm 0 WARFARE @mynameisjerm The term 'conspiracy theory' was weaponised by the CIA to shut down skepticism towards the government narrative around JFK's assassination. label critical analysis and dissenting viewpoints. Conspiracy theory is a term that at once strikes fear and anxiety in the hearts of most every public figure
column15: particularly journalists and academics. Since the 1960s the label has become a disciplinary device that has been overwhelmingly effective in defining certain events off limits to inquiry or debate. Especially in the United States raising legitimate questions about dubious official narratives destined to inform public opinion (and thereby public policy) is a major thought crime that must be cauterized from the public psyche at all costs. Conspiracy theory's acutely negative connotations may be traced to liberal historian Richard Hofstadter's well-known fusillades against the New Right. column3: (Now deleted) tweet claims that Julius Malema is sending himself death threats
column4: Complaint: DA Councillor Renaldo Gouws
column5: makes the claim that Julius Malema is sending himself racist death threats
column6: after Julius posted the message on Twitter.
column7: The tweet in question has been deleted. In any event
column8: while Renaldo's claim that if you type the number into TrueCaller you will get the same result is true
column9: this does not automatically confirm that the number is indeed Malema's due to the manner by which TrueCaller works - the platform's data is crowd-sourced from users who've downloaded the app onto their phones. This means that if enough users save the number as Malema's
column10: it will provide that as the result - particularly in the absence of any other data linked. [UPDATE: Tweet from Renaldo stating that he was not aware that Truecaller works in this way https://twitter.com/RenaldoGouws/status/1331930503201615873?s=20]

column3: Tweet claims that masks are unhealthy
column4: Tweet states amongst other things
column5: that masks are unhealthy and that masks constitute unscientific methods to stop the virus.
column6: The claim that masks are unhealthy is misinformation. It is not backed by any evidence. While the use of fabric masks is a robust measure to be combined with other prevention measures
column7: it is not infallible and has limited efficacy. https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-02801-8 However
column8: given that the current COVID-19 precaution measures include the wearing of masks
column9: completely denying the efficacy of masks (on a public platform such as Twitter) may result in non-compliance. This is disadvantageous. While the protection offered may be limited
column10: it does still work to some extent to limit the spread of COVID-19
column11: especially in crowded indoor spaces https://www.researchgate.net/publication/343234447_Efficacy_of_cloth_face_mask_in_prevention_of_novel_coronavirus_infection_transmission_A_systematic_review_and_meta-analysis. Given this risk

column3: Tweet claiming that 1 million school girls fell pregnant in South Africa this year.
column4: This complaint pertains to a tweet in which the tweet author states that 1 million school girls fell pregnant in South Africa this year with the inference that this high number is not necessarily due to rape or molestation but that receiving a child grant is incentive to fall pregnant.   The complaint is that this is mis- or disinformation.
column5: The claim of 1 000 000 schoolgirls falling pregnant in South Africa during the past year is likely significantly exaggerated. A report by IOL in 2019 quotes a number closer to 120 000 schoolgirl pregnancies for that year - https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/concern-as-more-than-120-000-schoolgirls-fall-pregnant-39196455  The rest of the content in the tweet falls in the category of opinion.

column3: Tweet and associated video claiming various inconsistencies and falsities in Dr  Zweli Mkhize's response to the Matric Rage super spreader events
column4: This complaint pertains to a tweet and video in which the author of both makes various statements pertaining to the inaccuracies
column5: inconsistencies and falsities in the recent response by Dr Zweli Mkhize as a result of the holding of Matric Rage events which have lead to an increase in COVID-19 infections and therefore been labelled super spreaders.   The complaint is that this video constitutes mis- or disinformation.
column6: The person in the video is misleading as to what Dr Mkhize has said. The organized Rage events as marketed by a particular firm have not all taken place. The Jeffrey's Bay event he mentions was scheduled by a firm (Howler) who have since cancelled there event. However
column7: the term rage and a matric rage is not trademarked or the domain of the organized events carrying that branding. Over the course of last week there was at least one rage party in Jeffrey's Bay. Dr Mkhize speaks of rage parties and even if there is a degree of miscommunication resulting in associating a specific series of events with something more generic the person in the video's approach is more misleading and inaccurate than any lost in translation effect from the general reporting.   Furthermore
column8: the person in the video takes an utterance from a single doctor in the area to make a number of conclusions about the safety of end-of-year matric parties and casts aspersions on all utterances by the minister of health.

column3: Tweet claiming that statement made by Dr Anthony Fauci
column4: an American physician and immunologist
column5: indicate that the testing system used in South Africa is junk science
column6: This complaint pertains to a tweet in which the tweet author claims that all information
column7: reports and statistics reported by the South African government and media is false. This statement is based on reference to a statement made by Dr Anthony Fauci pertaining to PCR cycles over 35 as being junk science. The tweet author states that South Africa utilises a 38 (approximate) cycle system.   The complaint is that this is mis- or disinformation.
column8: The tweet author is misquoting Dr Fauci. It is therefore misleading to suggest that amplification at more than 35 cycles is junk science and it is catagorically false to claim that What this means is that everything the government and media are telling
column10: from cases to infections to deaths.   PCR tests can generate a measurable amount of a thing from a very tiny sample if given enough cycles to run. That truth plays into the narrative in terms of a positive test being returned when the person perhaps had been exposed and recovered without even realising they were sick. It was still an infected person. Claiming otherwise is false.  the amount of virus in a sample is directly correlated with the number of amplification cycles needed to detect it
column11: a number known as its cycle threshold (Ct). A positive test that comes back positive in 20 cycles contains a greater amount of virus than one requiring 40 cycles. Right now
column12: we just call both results positive. But its obvious that the first sample came from an individual with a higher viral load. And the greater the viral load
column13: the more contagious the patient is likely to be.  There is some evidence that Ct values may be useful in predicting patients infectiousness and prognosis
column14: but were not yet at the point where it makes sense for us to include that information in our decision-making process at MIT
column15: says Associate Medical Director Shawn Ferullo. For one thing
column16: Ct values are not absolute. Different machines can produce different Ct values for the same sample
column17: and the same machine can give different Ct values for different samples from the same person. While it may be useful to know if an individuals Ct value is on the high or low end of the scale
column18: Ferullo says
column19: based on our current knowledge
column20: it would not change quarantine or self-isolation recommendations.  Source: https://medical.mit.edu/covid-19-updates/2020/11/pcr-test-result
column21: Resolved

column3: Newspaper article detailing sim swap scam
column4: This complaint pertains to a article from an unidentifiable publication in which the details of an allegedly new sim swap scam are presented and how to identify said scam and in turn protect yourself therefrom.   The complaint is that this is mis- or disinformation.
column5: While sim swap scams are legitimate to a degree
column6: the information contained in the article appears to be questionable.  That said
column7: while it appears to be questionable in reliability
column8: it does not pose a risk of causing public harm.   The following sources can provide information on sim swap scams and how to protect yourself from them: https://www.cnet.com/how-to/sim-swap-fraud-how-to-prevent-your-phone-number-from-being-stolen/   https://businesstech.co.za/news/telecommunications/275317/sim-swap-fraud-incidents-more-than-double-in-south-africa/

column3: Tweet: no actual proof that Rage event caused any issue
column4: Complainant states: Jonathan Witt claims that there is 'no actual proof' that the Rage events caused any issue
column5: which is inaccurate. He also implies that masks and lockdowns don't work
column6: then states that 'everything mainstream media is feeding you about Covid-19 is a lie' which is false.
column7: Stating that there is no actual proof that the Rage event caused any issue is denying that events such as these are risky and may lead behaviour that leads to an increase in COVID-19 infections. In light of the facts presented below
column8: this is misinformation. According to news reports
column9: a Durban doctor confirmed that 20 patients between the ages of 15-21 tested positive for COVID-19 in under 48 hours - all of whom had a link to Rage. [News24 report] Furthermore
column10: the NICD was alerted by general practitioners and community members claiming that there had been a rise in COVID-19 cases among people who had attended the Ballito Rage events. [Daily Maverick report] Furthermore
column11: an event such as Ballito has all the factors present to meet the criteria of a superspreader event: https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-superspreading-events-drive-most-covid-19-spread1/ Sources: https://www.news24.com/news24/southafrica/news/durban-super-spreader-events-could-cause-cluster-outbreaks-experts-warn-20201207 https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2020-12-07-ballito-rage-labelled-a-covid-super-spreader-event-joburg-and-jeffreys-bay-events-cancelled/

column3: Ad for Artemisia tea claims to relieve COVID-19 symptoms (and flu)
column4: Complainant states: This is fake news about Covid - a company is selling tea that it claims to cure Covid
column5: While this ad never expressly claims that Artemisia tea cures COVID-19
column6: there is a danger that this may be assumed. At worst
column7: this could delay someone from seeking treatment - which in severe cases
column8: would be detrimental. While some of the language may be misconstrued
column9: the wording used never explicitly claims that Artemisia tea (also locally known as lengana/ uMhlonyaneto) cure COVID-19. Rather
column10: it claims to alleviate symptoms associated with COVID-19
column11: or flu. The website claims the following: Traditionally used to relieve coughs
column13: fever and eases nasal congestion. There is insufficient evidence available to prove that drinking tea (particularly the type mentioned) has any curative effect on Covid. In terms of the claims about Artemisia particularly
column14: Poynter published fact-check reports earlier this year to confirm that there is no scientific evidence of its efficiency in terms of 'curing' Covid-19 - https://www.poynter.org/?ifcn_misinformation=who-said-artemisia-plant-cures-covid-19 and https://www.poynter.org/?ifcn_misinformation=artemisia-herbal-tea-was-certified-by-who-as-a-cure-for-covid-19. The Citizen also published an article that covered the teas and the role they play in health care
column15: but reasserted that they do not cure COVID-19 and they are not medical applications - https://citizen.co.za/lifestyle/2325112/these-traditional-african-teas-could-help-with-covid-19-symptoms/
column16: Resolved

column3: Second hand information pertaining to medical certification of deaths due to COVID-19
column4: This complaint pertains to a tweet in which the User relays information
column5: advice
column6: opinions from unsubstantiated third parties on the topic of medical certification of deaths due to COVID-19.   The complaint is that this information is inaccurate.
column7: The assertion we're simply labelling any death with a positive test in 30 days as Covid is misleading as it is information received from other people which cannot be substantiated and is therefore hearsay. As a result
column8: since the sources of the information cannot be substantiated
column9: the information has the propensity to mislead.   The intent of the content is to posit that the mortality and morbidity of the pandemic is being overstated. This narrative directly contributes to individuals not taking decisions which would reduce the impact of the pandemic.  https://www.nicd.ac.za/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Circular-Medical-certification-of-deaths-due-to-COVID-19.pdf

column3: NewEra postulating the efficacy of Ivermectin in treating COVID-19
column4: This complaint pertains to a Facebook post in which New Economic Rights Alliance (NewEra) detail the push for the use of Ivermectin in curbing the progression and spread of COVID-19.  The complain is that Insinuating that the government is withholding life saving medicine is misinformation.
column5: On 25 January 2021 the National Essential Medicines Committee COVID-19 sub-committee released the results of a rapid review of ivermectin for the prevention of COVID-19 in which they concluded that Overall
column6: the benefits and the harms of ivermectin for prophylaxis of COVDI-19 remains uncertain. The committee further suggests that ivermectin not be used routinely for COVID-19 except in the context of a clinical trial.   The subcommittee also released the results of a rapid review of ivermectin for the treatment of COVID-19 in which they concluded that There is currently insufficient evidence to recommend ivermectin for the treatment of patients with COVID-19. SAHPRA has also conducted a review of the new data and has arrived at the same conclusion as these esteemed
column7: independent review groups. SAHPRA has a team of expert reviewers on standby to review any new data on the use of ivermectin for the prevention and treatment of COVID-19 infections which are expected to become available in the forthcoming weeks and months.   In the interim
column8: as communicated at the press briefing of the 27 January 2021
column9: SAHPRA will implement a compassionate use access program via the legal framework of Section 21 of the Medicines and Related Substances Control Act (101 of 1965 as amended). Clear guidance on how this access programme will work will be published separately. This access programme will utilise the opportunity to collect much-needed data on the performance of ivermectin in South African patients through its COVI-VIG reporting platform.   Source: https://www.sahpra.org.za/press-releases/update-on-the-use-of-ivermectin-in-the-prevention-or-treatment-of-covid-19/

Happy to share reports on request. The product is an antiviral plant-based formulation that offers the following functionality as it relates to the current pandemic: 1) It inhibits viral latching to host cells (the mechanism for replication) by binding to the receptors 2) The flavonoids

column3: Telegram message insinuating the takeover of Africa by the Chinese
column4: This complaint pertains to a Telegram message in which the author of said message postulates that their is a Chinese Communistic takeover of Africa. In addition to making statements of divine guidance
column5: the author uses racial slurs targeting people of Chinese ethnicity. Furthermore
column6: specific statistics are quoted without proper supporting documents or sources.    The complaint is that this message constitutes hate speech.
column7: Misinformation:  The claims he makes about Chinese nationals are unfounded and inaccurate - currently
column8: numbers are reported at 300 000 - 400 000 as at 2015
column9: which is a far cry from the author's claims of 7 million. There also isn't any evidence to support the author's claims that they are all military trained and posing as shopkeepers
column10: who don't pay taxes and don't have visas.   The production of animosity and propagation of hatred (even if not constituting hate speech as defined under South African law) represents a public harm. This harm is not to the target group of hatred (for which incitement to cause a higher threshold of harm is required) but rather society as a whole.  Hate Speech: The advocacy of hatred criteria is met rather than mere expression. The expression of hatred is rooted in sinophobia and is thus on ethnicity grounds.  However
column11: an incitement to cause harm is not present and thus the message does not constitute hate speech.

column3: Video of medical professionals declaring COVID-19 as a fake pandemic as well as criticizing the efficacy and safety of the COVID-19 vaccines

The complaint is that the content of this video constitutes mis- or disinformation.
column5: Dr Johan Denis
column6: a GP from Belgium
column7: has consistently denied that COVID is real
column8: and declares that the pandemic is a worldwide conspiracy. He has now had his medical license withdrawn by the medical provincial commission
column9: and remains suspended until he indicates that he will follow the COVID rules. https://www.brusselstimes.com/news/belgium-all-news/151365/gp-who-claimed-covid-19-is-a-hoax-has-his-licence-suspended-ranst-mask-exception-conspiracy-high-risk/   Other medical professionals on the video (from a medical journalist

The claim that covid has the same mortality and morbidity as seasonal flu is false. The related claims against The claim it may change your DNA is false. The assertions around 5G and nanotechnology such that a person can be controlled is outright false. The claim that the vaccine has not been proved safe and effective is misleading and false. The claim that there is no medical pandemic is false.   The video must not be continued to be shared and circulated.

column3: Claim that disposable blue masks will cause lung cancer
column4: This complaint pertains to a Whatsapp message linking a news article in which various assertions pertaining to the safety of disposable blue masks are posited. The crux being that an asbestos-like substance has allegedly been used on said masks which can cause lung cancer in mask wearers.    The complaint is that this has been disproven and constitutes mis- or disinformation.
column5: The Canadian government issued an advisory against the use of a specific type of mask that contains the chemical graphene due to pulmonary toxicity concerns. The use of blue disposable face masks in fear-mongering headlines falsely suggests this warning applies to all blue disposable face masks. In fact
column6: only a small subset of masks contain graphene. No scientific consensus exists on graphene's purported antiviral properties (which provided the justification for their use in masks) or its toxicity (which formed the basis for the advisory notice). Most disposable blue face masks are unaffected by the news discussed in these claims.    Source: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/blue-masks-asbestos/
column7: Resolved

column11: that people must stand strong against vaccination at all costs

column3: YouTube: Interview with Dr who authored a COVID-19 conspiracy book
column4: Part of the complaint reads: This is a Doctor spreading false information about covid. He has a book out about how covid is a scam...
column5: The claims made by the speaker amount to mis/disinformation and his objectivity should be questioned as he is simultaneously promoting a book that he authored. He discounts accepted measures to prevent infection
column6: which in turn could put lives at risk. In addition
column7: the speaker admits during the interview that there are mistakes in his book. The interview covers three main topics: comments on ivermectin
column8: herd immunity (the interviewee's opinions on why measures to prevent the spread of infection are ineffective) and comments on COVID vaccines. During the interview
column9: the individual makes several comments that qualify as mis- information and disinformation. For example: 1. He claims there are no studies that prove mask efficacy - https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-02801-8 2. He claims face masks cause hypoxia - https://www.mayoclinichealthsystem.org/hometown-health/speaking-of-health/debunked-myths-about-face-masks 3 - He claims that COVID vaccines has the potential to destroy DNA - https://www.bbc.com/news/54893437

column3: Tweet featuring image of polio patients in Sierra Leone
column4: The complainant states: The tweet states that a lot of people who got vaccinated are not well anymore. There is no scientific evidence or statistics to support such statement. This can very dangerous as government is trying to vaccinate more and more south Africans.
column5: This is disinformation. The image used has been fact-checked here: https://factcheck.afp.com/1998-photo-shows-young-polio-patients-sierra-leone. There is no evidence for the claim that those who have taken the vaccine are on anti-depressants. Evidence is in fact that those who are already suffering from severe mental illness need vaccines more urgently as they are at greater risk from COVID-19 https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanpsy/article/PIIS2215-0366(20)30564-2/fulltext  The tweet has been reported to Twitter

column3: Tweet: illegal immigrants accused of crimes in xenophobic manner
column4: The complainant states: The tweet states that foreigners are busy killing South Africans daily. The intention here is to galvanize support
column5: to encourage South Africans to hate foreign nationals.
column6: While the contents of the tweet and the use of the hashtag #PutSouthAficansFirst is strongly indicative of xenophobia
column7: it does not satisfy the legal criteria for hate speech and incitement to violence as it is: (1) not specific enough in the action called for; and (2) accordingly
column8: not a strong enough correlation between this statement and the probability of public violence occurring. That said
column9: it is nevertheless abhorrent and will be reported to Xenowatch and Twitter for monitoring. While the complaint was not lodged under the heading of disinformation
column10: the statement made is unfounded and hyperbolic and aims to further exacerbate an anti-foreigner sentiment and therefore constitutes disinformation.

column7: The author makes a number of concerning and misleading claims. As evidenced in the following article
column8: the email is far from a credible source for COVID-19's origins: https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2021/06/03/fact-check-email-fauci-doesnt-contain-origin-coronavirus/7511931002/. The text of Gaertners email was taken word-for-word from a 2005 paper by a team of researchers at the University of Pennsylvania. At the time
column9: they were trying to find a way to block the activation of a SARS-CoV spike protein as a potential therapeutic for severe acute respiratory syndrome
column10: which is caused by the virus
column12: a co-author of the study and microbiology professor at the University of Pennsylvania. Gaertner focused on one portion of the paper titled intervirion fusion
column13: which he sent to Fauci. But one of Bates co-authors
column14: Graham Simmons
column15: told USA TODAY that Gaertner misinterpreted it. Both Bates and Simmons said the virus particles used in the experiment didnt contain genetic material from a coronavirus. The claim that an email to Fauci contained the origins of the coronavirus is FALSE
column16: based on the research conducted by USA Today. The text of the email is lifted from a research paper published in 2005
column17: more than a decade before the emergence of COVID-19. Hogg suggests that masks are useless because of an email from February 2020 in which Fauci corrects himself to say ... most transmissions occur from someone who is symptomatic - not asymptomatic. The email predates the realisation of the efficacy of masks in March/April 2020. Later in June
column18: Fauci stated: the evidence we have given the percentage of people
column19: which is about 25% [to] 45%
column20: of the totality of infected people likely are without symptoms. He went on to add that ... we know from epidemiological studies that they can transmit to someone who is uninfected even when they are without symptoms. Hogg advocates for HCQ using an email from March 2020 - an email that references a study serving only as a basis for ongoing clinical trials and advocates only that there MIGHT be a more cost-effective treatment for the Coronavirus. In June of the same year
column21: the FDA revoked the emergency use authorisation (EUA) for HCQ for the treatment of COVID-19 after results from several clinical trials failed to show that HCQ could be safe and effective for treating or preventing COVID-19.

column3: Tweet: cites report to further anti-vaccine agenda
column4: Complainant states: This person claims that the vaccination roll-out is unethical and immoral.
column5: The way in which the report is being cited seeks to promote a particular agenda . The report being cited and its appearance as an image is perfectly accurate and an important contribution to public discourse and understanding. HOWEVER the editorializing in the Tweet is misleading and is putting words into the report that simply aren't there. The report https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7996517/pdf/medicina-57-00199.pdf relates to the specific disclosures and fallacies in statistical data presentation by manufacturers of particular vaccines to specific regulators. To jump from manufacturers violated their ethical obligations in the manner in which they disclosed information such as to distort the efficacy and risks is quite different from the vaccine campaign is an unethical and immoral sham.
column6: Resolved
column7: Twitter
column10: the vaccine campaign is an unethical and immoral sham. 5. Conclusions A critical appraisal of phase III clinical trial data for the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine BNT162b2 and Moderna vaccine mRNA-1273 shows that absolute risk reduction measures are very much lower than the reported relative risk reduction measures. Yet
column11: the manufac- turers failed to report absolute risk reduction measures in publicly released documents. As well
column12: the U.S FDA Advisory Committee (VRBPAC) did not follow FDA published guidelines for communicating risks and benefits to the public
column13: and the committee failed 7 of 8 to report absolute risk reduction measures in authorizing the BNT162b2 and mRNA-1273 vaccines for emergency use. Such examples of outcome reporting bias mislead and distort the public's interpretation of COVID-19 mRNA vaccine efficacy and violate the ethical and  legal obligations of informed consent. |

column15: Solstice  Mindful Moment 22 June Winter Solstice Peace  WHY WE GOT COVID AND HOW WE SURVIVED Published June 19
column16: 2021 | By Nicola Aylward We got Covid. Just last week. And it was very unexpected. One wonders how it can be unexpected in a time when it's all around us and it's on everyone's lips and constantly in our thoughts. But we thought we'd had it when we went skiing in France in January 2020 - we returned full of flu - so much so that our children missed their first 3 days of school. And we went to our GP for help. We hadn't seen her in over 8 years. She even did a swab sample of Philippa
column17: but by the time we knew about Covid-19
column18: and we asked the lab to retest
column19: they couldn't locate the sample. And we've been pretty active during this last year. We felt that we had to have been exposed to it and we must have the  antibodies so that's why we hadn't caught Covid |

column5: commenters provide anecdotal evidence of vaccine injuries and deaths without evidence.    The complaint is that this constitutes mis- or disinformation.
column6: As yet
column7: no deaths have been reported in South Africa from vaccination. There have been cases of side effects
column9: but not death. This may be a litigious attempt against government/vaccination providers.

column3: COVID-19 mis- or disinformation regarding vaccination and the emergence of new variants of SARS-CoV-2
column4: The Tweet by Richard Spoor falsely claims that a paper published in Nature explains how mass vaccination during a pandemic can give rise to dangerous new strains.
column5: The publication constitutes mis- or disinformation. The article discusses antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) and SARS-CoV-2 vaccines and therapies. The article concludes that clinical data has not yet fully established a role for ADE in human COVID-19 pathology. The article does not explain how mass vaccination during a pandemic can give rise to dangerous new strains. In the current context
column6: the false information expressed in the Tweet could reasonably be construed to induce vaccine hesitancy. This may increase the transmission of SARS-CoV-2
column7: and cause severe public harm.

column6: and undermine public trust in science.

column5: The publication constitutes mis- or disinformation. The false information could reasonably induce vaccine hesitancy
column6: promote low rates of vaccine acceptance
column7: and undermine public trust in science.

column3: False information about Covid-19 vaccines and PCR tests.
column4: The article contains false information about the Covid-19
column5: the Covid-19 vaccine and PCR tests.
column6: The publication constitutes mis- or disinformation. It makes a variety of false claims that are devoid of any basis in fact. It is
column7: for example
column8: false that the 'mRNA vaccines in current use are now scientifically linked to hospitalizations and deaths.' It is also false that the 'coronavirus PCR test has no capacity to differentiate between SARS-CoV-2 and a variety of viruses that cause flu or the common cold.' The PCR tests in use accurately detect SARS-CoV-2 in respiratory specimens. It is also false that 'mRNA vaccines are the product of experimental scientific research that has not met accepted international standards to be declared safe or effective in animal or human subjects.' It is also false that health authorities 'do not know whether the experimental coronavirus mRNA vaccines are safe
column9: nor how effective they may be  ' It is also false that the South African government has failed to publish statistics about vaccine adverse events. In the current context
column10: the false information in the publication could reasonably be construed to induce vaccine hesitancy
